description: From New Latin cȳma (“young sprout or shoot of cabbage”) (whence the botanic usage of cyme), from Ancient Greek κῦμα (kûma, “swell, wave”, “cyma”, “sprout of a plant”), from κύω (kúō, “I conceive, I become pregnant”).

nouns.description: cyma (plural cymas or cymae or cymæ or cymata)

entries.meaning: (architecture) A moulding of the cornice, wavelike in form, whose outline consists of a concave and a convex line; an ogee.
